advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>I bellissimi...<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, FEB 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color ="#666666">The Altos ACS8000-6 series. It's a barrier breaker in every sense. Our entry level, single-user, hard-disk system with floppy backup is priced under $10,000...<br> ... With MP/M at the helm, your Altos system can support up to four simulteneous users with 48 KB RAM each plus 58 MB of Winchester storage and 4 MB of floppy backup. And that adds up to the first microcomputer to give you the power and performance of a minicomputer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT APR. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...If you want a computer that won't be obsolete in a few years, buy an MSX.<br> If you want one of the best-selling MSX computers in Japan, buy a Toshiba HX10.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #4(1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The users featured in the ad said:<br><br> (left) <i>Programming is a snap! I'm halfway through Apple's BASIC manual and already I've programmed my own Star Wars game.</i><br><br> ...with half of the universe<br><br> (middle) <i>Those math programs I wrote last week - I just rewrote them using Apple's mini assembler and got them to run a hundred time faster.</i><br><br> Of course, it's very easy for a newbie programmer to program maths assembly routines with a microprocessor which only knows how to add and subtract integer values.<br><br> (right)<i>Apple's smart peripherals make expansion easy. Just plug'em it and you are ready to run. I've already added two disks, a printer and a communication card.</i></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert tried to convince computers newcomers that a pocket computer could do the same as a desktop computer...<br><br><font color="#666666"> Now Texas Instruments brings you a cordless compact computer that solves the same sort of problems as the Apple or IBM Personal Computer...<br><br> ...For most personal computer tasks, its 6K RAM and 34K ROM are ample...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #3 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>As harware arguments wasn't sufficient, NothStar tried to promote software compatability and services.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IIE VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture. Notice the dual floppy drive module on top of the case, inspired by the Franklin <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/computer.asp?st=1&c=646" target="_blank">ACE 1200</a><p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Canon AS-100. Programmed to succeed."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Large achievement capability and high versatility with 64kb RAM." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used to promote the educative potential of the TO-7/70. This poor student is studying economic politics... <br><br> As usual, no cables are shown... the tape recorder is thus useless... Will someone tell him ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World, October 1983<br><br> Here are some answers:<br><font color="#666666"> "The BBC Microcomputers are the limousines of home computers. The graphics are probably the best' of any machine in this class. You are paying for Ii smart machine which would not disgrace the home of a professional."<br> <i>Video World., Feb. '83.</i><br><br> "Its design has given the BBC Micro an unrivalled potential for business, educational and serious home applications. It has been equipped to function as the heart of a system which can be expanded 10 suit its owner's need?"<br> <i>Which Micro & Software Review, Feb. '81</i><br><br> "The most attractive and exciting feature of the BBC Microcomputer is its enormous potential for expansion which will allow a higly expansive system to be built-up?"<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "They (the graphics) are tremendously exciting, and they are one of the features that make this machine stand out head and shoulders above everything else that is available in the market place at this time"<br> <i>Educalional Computing, May '82</i><br><br> "It is expandable and has a powerful BASIC. It has superb sound and graphics, the software is readily available and the price is righ"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Hampshire.</i><br><br> "The basics are easy to follow. My wife has developed a program for teaching our daughter French vocabulary. Our daughter uses it mainly for games and simple programming"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Co. Durham.</i><br><br> "It is a very powerful computer, My husband has written his own data base. I have been writing programs and programming games. Even the children have written small programs."<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Devon.</i><br><br> "No other computer can offer such ease of use when dealing with complex sound effects."<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "It isn't often a journalist can sit down to write about a computer with the certain knowledge that he has never seen a nicer machine."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, Dec. '82</i> "It has got huge potential. Besides playing the games, the whole family are learning basic programming."<br> <i>A BBC Micro owner from Staffordshire.</i><br><br> "Everything possible seems to have been done to ensure that this is not a 'dead end' machine.."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, July '82.</i></font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Speed serves business.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1946...</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an extract of the promotional guide. It says: <br><br> <font color="#666666">1946... Today the TO 7<br> 1946: 30 tons, 160 m²<br> Today: 3.5 Kg, 0.01 m²</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 464 - 6128 PERIPHERALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top left to bottom right:<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 6128<br> - Joystick with joystick adaptor<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 464<br> - Disc drive with interface and CP/M for CPC 464<br> - Speech synthesizer and stereo amplifier<br> - Additional disc drive<br> - Light pen with graphics software<br> - RS232 interface<br> - DMP 2000 dot printer</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new revolutionnary modular system" <br><br> So you say... <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence" <br><br> Not less ! </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 1 - Tennis (2 players)2 - Hockey (2 players)3 - Handball (1 players)4 - Jai-Alai (2 player)
computer.description:
After the release of the Telstar (the first "dedicated-chip" pong system) in 1976 which was a big success, Coleco conceived a whole range of pongs for release at Christmas 1977. The Telstar Alpha is one of the simplest system of the range. It offers only four games and has built-in controllers. That's cool if you want to play 2 players games alone ! The only difference between the original Telstar and the alpha is that there is one more game on the Alpha (Jai-Alai).
There's a 3 positions switch that controls difficulty (BEGINNER : slow ball, big paddles / INTERMEDIATE : slow ball, small paddles / PRO : fast ball, big paddles). If this is common to the first Telstars, this is quite different from most of the other pong systems which offer individual settings.
computer.language: 1 - Tennis (2 players)2 - Hockey (2 players)3 - Handball (1 players)4 - Jai-Alai (2 player)
computer.name: Telstar Alpha - Model #6030
